comments.body: Could use some docs/comments explaining what the stats.custom data structure looks like.
its up to the user, the top level is just the 'var name of the stat', after that it can be anything
Splitting this block (273-286) into it's own method would make it easier for sub classes of the default CallbackModule (like debug, skippy, actionable, dense) to extend this behavior.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +271,275 @@        # print custom stats
        if C.SHOW_CUSTOM_STATS and stats.custom:
            self._display.banner("CUSTOM STATS: ")
            # per host
            #TODO: come up with 'pretty format'

@@ -1,1 +147,151 @@
            # Display the task banner immediately if we're not doing any filtering based on task result
            if self._plugin_options.get('display_skipped_hosts') and self._plugin_options.get('display_ok_hosts'):
                self._print_task_banner(task)

@@ -1,1 +159,163 @@
            # Display the task banner immediately if we're not doing any filtering based on task result
            if (self._plugin_options.get('display_skipped_hosts', DEFAULT_DISPLAY_SKIPPED_HOSTS) and
                    self._plugin_options.get('display_ok_hosts', DEFAULT_DISPLAY_OK_HOSTS)):
                self._print_task_banner(task)

comments.body:
I was thinking that we should show them as subgroups, otherwise task numbers don't match up:  
```
 u"%s : %s(%s) %s %s %s(%s) %s " %``
...
colorize(u'ok', t['ok'], C.COLOR_OK), 
colorize(u'rescued', t['rescued'], C.COLOR_OK),
...
 colorize(u'failed', t['failures'], C.COLOR_ERROR),
colorize(u'ignored', t['ignored'], C.COLOR_WARN),
```

But `rescued` tasks are not counted as `ok` so unsure `ok=X (rescued=Y)` makes sense? Not sure `failed=X (ignored=Y)` makes sense either since those two are mutually exclusive, you can have either one or the other.

See this playbook and its recap:
```
- hosts: localhost
  gather_facts: no
  tasks:
    - name: ok1
      debug:

    - name: ok2 and changed
      debug:
      changed_when: True

    - name: skipped
      debug:
      when: False

    - block:
        - name: rescued
          fail:
      rescue:
        - name: ok3
          debug:

    - name: ok4 and ignored
      fail:
      ignore_errors: yes

    - name: failed
      fail:
```

`localhost                  : ok=4    changed=1    unreachable=0    failed=1    skipped=1    rescued=1    ignored=1`

Task numbers don't match up because `changed` and `ignored` are counted as `ok` as well.
I seem to have confused the accounting, so `ok (ignored)` .. i assumed rescued was 'failed but rescued' but it seems to account for 'rescue tasks run'?

If we do `ok (ignore)`, should we do also `ok (changed)`, so `ok=X (changed=Y, ignored=Z)` then? Because task number hasn't been matched up ever as `changed` tasks are counted as `ok` too.

No, `rescued` are 'failed but rescued' tasks, but they are NOT counted as `failed` so in the example above it's
```
        - name: rescued
          fail:
```
so `rescued=1` (and `failed=0` if it was just this block).
yeah, i think that will alleviate a lot of confusion with the status of tasks

comments.body:
The code is implemented there but with the options only existing in the default callback plugin, there is no way to enable it with other callback plugins. 

I would suggest removing this note and moving the `check_mode_markers` documentation to the default doc fragment (`lib/ansible/plugins/doc_fragments/default_callback.py`). This will allow the setting to be controlled from all those plugins as well as update the documentation for all those plugins.

Hello, please have a look at [comment](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/pull/49432#issuecomment-485834431) above for clarification, regarding a discussion we had with bcoca about this.

In short, there are plugins which use the default callback's doc fragment but do not inherit from it (like others).

So in the present situation of this patch, where documentation is in the default plugin, there is an undocumented feature for the three mentioned plugins. 

On the other hand if I move the documentation to the default callback's doc fragment, there will be 2 plugins that will have their documentation mention the feature but in fact do not implement it.
Ok. I did not see that previous discussion.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +34,38 @@'''

# NOTE: check_mode_markers functionality is also implemented in the following derived plugins:
#       debug.py, yaml.py, dense.py. Maybe their documentation needs updating, too.
